questions.question: Which bone forms the posterior part of the hard palate?
questions.explanation: The palatine bone forms the posterior one-third of the hard palate.

questions.question: The brachial artery divides into radial and ulnar arteries at the level of:
questions.explanation: The brachial artery bifurcates at the neck of the radius into radial and ulnar arteries.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for facial expression?
questions.explanation: Cranial nerve VII (facial nerve) controls the muscles of facial expression.

questions.question: The thoracic duct drains lymph into:
questions.hint: It drains into the venous system on the left side of the body at the junction of internal jugular and subclavian veins.
questions.explanation: The thoracic duct drains into the left subclavian vein at its junction with the internal jugular vein.

questions.question: Which muscle is the primary flexor of the forearm?
questions.explanation: The brachialis muscle is the primary flexor of the forearm at the elbow joint.

questions.question: Normal resting heart rate in adults is:
questions.explanation: The normal resting heart rate for adults is 60-100 beats per minute.

questions.question: The pacemaker of the heart is:
questions.explanation: The sinoatrial (SA) node is the natural pacemaker of the heart.

questions.question: Normal blood pressure in adults is:
questions.explanation: Normal blood pressure is considered to be 120/80 mmHg or lower.

questions.question: The functional unit of the kidney is:
questions.explanation: The nephron is the functional unit of the kidney, consisting of a glomerulus and tubular system.

questions.question: Insulin is produced by which cells in the pancreas?
questions.explanation: Beta cells in the islets of Langerhans produce insulin in response to glucose.

questions.question: Which enzyme is deficient in phenylketonuria?
questions.explanation: Phenylalanine hydroxylase deficiency causes phenylketonuria (PKU).

questions.question: The end product of purine metabolism is:
questions.explanation: Uric acid is the end product of purine metabolism in humans.

questions.question: Which vitamin is synthesized by gut bacteria?
questions.explanation: Vitamin K is synthesized by gut bacteria and is essential for blood clotting.

questions.question: The rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis is:
questions.hint: This enzyme catalyzes the conversion of fructose-6-phosphate to fructose-1,6-bisphosphate and is the main regulatory point.
questions.explanation: Phosphofructokinase (PFK) is the rate-limiting enzyme of glycolysis and the main control point.

questions.question: Which amino acid is converted to serotonin?
questions.explanation: Tryptophan is converted to serotonin via 5-hydroxytryptophan.

questions.question: Which type of necrosis is characteristic of myocardial infarction?
questions.explanation: Coagulative necrosis is characteristic of myocardial infarction, preserving tissue architecture initially.

questions.question: The most common type of lung cancer is:
questions.explanation: Adenocarcinoma is now the most common type of lung cancer, especially in non-smokers.

questions.question: Reed-Sternberg cells are characteristic of:
questions.explanation: Reed-Sternberg cells are pathognomonic for Hodgkin lymphoma.

questions.question: Which marker is elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP) is elevated in hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.question: The most common cause of acute pancreatitis is:
questions.explanation: Gallstones are the most common cause of acute pancreatitis.

questions.question: Which drug is a beta-blocker?
questions.explanation: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-adrenergic receptor blocker.

questions.question: The antidote for warfarin overdose is:
questions.explanation: Vitamin K is the antidote for warfarin overdose as it helps synthesize clotting factors.

questions.question: Which antibiotic inhibits protein synthesis?
questions.explanation: Streptomycin is an aminoglycoside that inhibits protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit.

questions.question: The mechanism of action of aspirin is:
questions.hint: Aspirin irreversibly acetylates both cyclooxygenase enzymes, but has different affinities for each.
questions.explanation: Aspirin irreversibly inhibits both COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes through acetylation.

questions.question: Which drug is used to treat opioid overdose?
questions.explanation: Naloxone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reverse opioid overdose.

questions.question: Which bacteria is the most common cause of urinary tract infections?
questions.explanation: E. coli is responsible for about 80-85% of uncomplicated urinary tract infections.

questions.question: The causative agent of tuberculosis is:
questions.explanation: Mycobacterium tuberculosis is the causative agent of tuberculosis.

questions.question: Which virus causes infectious mononucleosis?
questions.explanation: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is the most common cause of infectious mononucleosis.

questions.question: Clostridium difficile infection is associated with:
questions.explanation: C. difficile infection is commonly associated with antibiotic use that disrupts normal gut flora.

questions.question: The most effective method of sterilization is:
questions.explanation: Moist heat sterilization using an autoclave is the most effective method of sterilization.

questions.question: The most common cause of heart failure is:
questions.explanation: Coronary artery disease is the leading cause of heart failure in developed countries.

questions.question: Which is the first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes?
questions.explanation: Metformin is the first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes mellitus.

questions.question: The classic triad of symptoms in diabetes mellitus includes:
questions.explanation: The classic triad of diabetes is polyuria (excessive urination), polydipsia (excessive thirst), and polyphagia (excessive hunger).

questions.question: Which condition is characterized by the presence of Kayser-Fleischer rings?
questions.hint: This is a genetic disorder affecting copper metabolism, and the rings are seen in the cornea.
questions.explanation: Wilson's disease is characterized by Kayser-Fleischer rings due to copper deposition in the cornea.

questions.question: The most common cause of chronic kidney disease is:
questions.explanation: Diabetes mellitus is the leading cause of chronic kidney disease worldwide.

questions.question: The most common cause of small bowel obstruction is:
questions.explanation: Adhesions from previous surgery are the most common cause of small bowel obstruction.

questions.question: McBurney's point is associated with:
questions.explanation: McBurney's point is the point of maximum tenderness in acute appendicitis.

questions.question: The gold standard for diagnosing acute cholangitis is:
questions.explanation: ERCP (Endoscopic Retrograde Cholangiopancreatography) is the gold standard for diagnosing acute cholangitis.

questions.question: Charcot's triad consists of:
questions.explanation: Charcot's triad consists of fever, jaundice, and right upper quadrant pain, seen in acute cholangitis.

questions.question: The most common type of thyroid cancer is:
questions.explanation: Papillary thyroid carcinoma is the most common type of thyroid cancer.

questions.question: The most common cause of pneumonia in children under 2 years is:
questions.explanation: RSV is the most common cause of pneumonia in children under 2 years of age.

questions.question: At what age should solid foods be introduced to infants?
questions.explanation: Solid foods should be introduced around 6 months of age according to current guidelines.

questions.question: The most common congenital heart defect is:
questions.explanation: Ventricular septal defect (VSD) is the most common congenital heart defect.

questions.question: Kawasaki disease primarily affects:
questions.explanation: Kawasaki disease is a systemic vasculitis that primarily affects medium-sized arteries.

questions.question: The vaccine for measles, mumps, and rubella (MMR) is typically given at:
questions.explanation: The first MMR vaccine is typically given at 12-15 months of age.

questions.question: The most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage is:
questions.explanation: Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.question: Folic acid supplementation during pregnancy helps prevent:
questions.explanation: Folic acid supplementation helps prevent neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.question: The normal duration of pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: Normal pregnancy duration is 40 weeks from the last menstrual period.

questions.question: HELLP syndrome consists of:
options: Hemolysis, elevated liver enzymes, low platelets
Headache, elevated BP, liver pain, proteinuria
questions.hint: This is a severe form of preeclampsia with specific laboratory findings affecting blood cells, liver, and platelets.
questions.explanation: HELLP syndrome consists of Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, and Low Platelets.

questions.question: The most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive age women is:
questions.explanation: Anovulation is the most common cause of abnormal uterine bleeding in reproductive age women.

questions.question: The most common mental health disorder is:
questions.explanation: Anxiety disorders are the most common mental health disorders globally.

questions.question: The first-line treatment for major depressive disorder is:
questions.explanation: SSRIs (Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors) are the first-line treatment for major depression.

questions.question: Positive symptoms of schizophrenia include:
questions.explanation: Positive symptoms of schizophrenia include hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking.

questions.question: The diagnostic criteria for ADHD require symptoms to be present before age:
questions.explanation: ADHD diagnostic criteria require symptoms to be present before age 12 years.

questions.question: Lithium is primarily used to treat:
questions.explanation: Lithium is primarily used as a mood stabilizer in the treatment of bipolar disorder.

questions.question: The best imaging modality for acute stroke is:
questions.explanation: CT scan is the best initial imaging for acute stroke as it's fast and can rule out hemorrhage.

questions.question: Which imaging is contraindicated in pregnancy?
questions.explanation: CT scans involve ionizing radiation and should be avoided in pregnancy when possible.

questions.question: The gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism is:
questions.explanation: CT pulmonary angiogram (CTPA) is the gold standard for diagnosing pulmonary embolism.

questions.question: Pneumoperitoneum on chest X-ray indicates:
questions.explanation: Pneumoperitoneum (free air under the diaphragm) indicates perforated viscus.

questions.question: The most sensitive imaging for detecting bone metastases is:
questions.explanation: Bone scan (scintigraphy) is the most sensitive imaging for detecting bone metastases.

questions.question: The most common type of skin cancer is:
questions.explanation: Basal cell carcinoma is the most common type of skin cancer.

questions.question: Psoriasis is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Psoriasis is characterized by well-demarcated plaques with silvery scales.

questions.question: The most common cause of erythema nodosum is:
questions.explanation: Most cases of erythema nodosum are idiopathic (no identifiable cause).

questions.question: Nikolsky's sign is positive in:
questions.explanation: Nikolsky's sign is positive in pemphigus vulgaris and other blistering disorders.

questions.question: The first-line treatment for mild acne is:
questions.explanation: Topical retinoids are the first-line treatment for mild acne.

questions.question: The most common cause of blindness worldwide is:
questions.explanation: Cataracts are the leading cause of blindness worldwide, though they are treatable.

questions.question: Normal intraocular pressure is:
questions.explanation: Normal intraocular pressure ranges from 10-21 mmHg.

questions.question: The most common type of glaucoma is:
questions.explanation: Primary open-angle glaucoma is the most common type of glaucoma.

questions.question: Diabetic retinopathy screening should begin:
questions.hint: The timing differs between Type 1 and Type 2 diabetes due to different disease progression patterns.
questions.explanation: Screening begins 5 years after diagnosis for Type 1 diabetes and at diagnosis for Type 2 diabetes.

questions.question: The most common cause of acute red eye is:
questions.explanation: Conjunctivitis is the most common cause of acute red eye.

questions.question: The most common cause of conductive hearing loss in children is:
questions.explanation: Otitis media is the most common cause of conductive hearing loss in children.

questions.question: Weber test lateralizes to the affected ear in:
questions.explanation: In conductive hearing loss, the Weber test lateralizes to the affected (worse) ear.

questions.question: The most common cause of epistaxis is:
questions.explanation: Bleeding from Kiesselbach's plexus (anterior nasal septum) is the most common cause of epistaxis.

questions.question: Meniere's disease is characterized by:
questions.explanation: Meniere's disease is characterized by the triad of hearing loss, vertigo, and tinnitus.

questions.question: The most common malignant tumor of the larynx is:
questions.explanation: Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumor of the larynx.

questions.question: The most common type of hip fracture in elderly is:
questions.explanation: Intertrochanteric fractures are the most common type of hip fracture in elderly patients.

questions.question: Carpal tunnel syndrome affects which nerve?
questions.explanation: Carpal tunnel syndrome involves compression of the median nerve at the wrist.

questions.question: The unhappy triad consists of tears to:
questions.explanation: The unhappy triad consists of tears to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus.

questions.question: Osgood-Schlatter disease affects:
questions.explanation: Osgood-Schlatter disease affects the knee, specifically the tibial tuberosity.

questions.question: The most common location for osteosarcoma is:
questions.explanation: The distal femur is the most common location for osteosarcoma.

questions.question: The most common type of stroke is:
questions.explanation: Ischemic stroke accounts for about 85% of all strokes.

questions.question: The classic triad of Parkinson's disease includes:
questions.explanation: The classic triad of Parkinson's disease is tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

questions.question: Multiple sclerosis primarily affects:
questions.explanation: Multiple sclerosis primarily affects white matter through demyelination.

questions.question: The most common cause of dementia is:
questions.explanation: Alzheimer's disease is the most common cause of dementia.

questions.question: Status epilepticus is defined as seizure activity lasting longer than:
questions.explanation: Status epilepticus is defined as seizure activity lasting longer than 5 minutes.

questions.question: The first step in managing cardiac arrest is:
questions.explanation: High-quality CPR should be started immediately in cardiac arrest.

questions.question: The antidote for acetaminophen overdose is:
questions.explanation: N-acetylcysteine is the antidote for acetaminophen (paracetamol) overdose.

questions.question: Beck's triad is associated with:
questions.explanation: Beck's triad (elevated JVP, hypotension, muffled heart sounds) is associated with cardiac tamponade.

questions.question: The Glasgow Coma Scale ranges from:
questions.explanation: The Glasgow Coma Scale ranges from 3 (worst) to 15 (best).

questions.question: The most common cause of upper GI bleeding is:
questions.explanation: Peptic ulcer disease is the most common cause of upper GI bleeding.
